content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really creative and interesting clash. I enjoyed solving it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a very unique and interesting Task. While reading the rules and going through the examples you instantly get ideas how to solve it. I am sure that the task will be a good addition to the pool of challenges.

The following tests can be added:

Input:
repeat
repeat1 repeat2 repeat3 lol repeat3 repeat2 repeat1
Output:
repeat - 80 %
lol - 20 %

Input:
very
it's a very nice clash. Very very nice and very interesting. Yes, I said "very".
Output:
nice - 50 %
very - 25 %
interesting - 25 %

NB: Outputs do not take into account the case where [[word]] is the last word.

Very nice and original, thx.

About the last constraint ("word" is never the last etc) maybe you can:

- Either suppress the end "if word appears only once in trainingData", because there is no such a testcase even when word appears more than 1 time. This is the simplest.

- Either ask to print "FOLLOWED BY NOTHING" (or other mention) with the percentage when the word is followed by a "." or at the end of the trainingData after substitution of chars /[^A-Za-z\.\- ]/ by "" (maybe this regex is not completely true). This may be too difficult in 15 min.

Anyway, clearly an upvote for me, and approbation for soon

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is original and interesting, it looks good against the plenty of template problems.

The next step would be "one-line self-attention".
In any case, funny and smart!
Maybe you should put a test/validator where the appearance order doesn't match the order of probability?

Goal
* The hint is a bit unclear… I have to think a bit to get what you mean. Suggest to delete the hint ("hint" sounds optional) and add three rules instead:

A hyphenated word is considered as one word.
Punctuations (other than hyphens) are ignored when counting the next words.
Letter case is ignored for the baseline word and the next words.

Output
* Please delete "n lines with".

* Please add ", one line for each word" after "probability".

* Please specify the rounding requirement of the percentages.

* Please add "The format of each line is:".

* Please format "-" and "%" as {{constants}}.

Constraints
* Please mention that [[word]] always appears at least once in [[trainingData]] ignoring the letter case.

* Please mention that [[word]] is never the last word in [[trainingData]] if [[word]] appears only once in [[trainingData]].

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement, e.g. "write answer".

Cases
* Each pair of cases should be similar, hence:

  • Please swap Test 1 and Test 2.
  
  • Please swap Validator 2 and Test 3.
  
  • For Test 3, please change the baseline word so that the required output also contains 100%.
  
  • For Test 4, please change the baseline word to lowercase.

* Please add a pair of cases where the baseline [[word]] is a hyphenated word, some of the next words are immediately followed by a punctuation, and all output percentages require rounding.

* Please add a pair of cases where the output contains hyphenated words, some of the next words are immediately followed by a punctuation, and all output percentages require rounding.

Thanks.
Thanks a lot, I used most of your advice.

It looks better now. Points to follow up:

Goal
* Please mention that due to rounding, the output percentages may not add up to 100%.

Output
* Please format "trainingData" as a [[variable]].

* Please specify the rounding requirement of the percentages.

Constraints
* 3rd constraint:
(a) Please fix the [[variable]] format syntax for "word" and "trainingData".

(b) Please add "ignoring the letter case".

* Please mention that [[word]] is never the last word in [[trainingData]] if [[word]] appears only once in [[trainingData]].

(Because in this case there won't be any [[followingWord]].)

Cases
* Please add a pair of cases where the baseline [[word]] (i.e. input line 1) is a hyphenated word, some of the next words are immediately followed by a punctuation, and all output percentages require rounding.

Thanks.
